awd_titl_txt: Transitional Justice and the Quality of Political Representation:  Testing the Empirical Implications of a Formal Model
awd_abstract_narration:
General Abstract	
This research investigates how former authoritarian elites utilize the secret information acquired by the former enforcement apparatus associated with their respective regimes.  The project seeks to learn whether such information can be used to blackmail politicians to make policy concessions, or whether previously undisclosed information about human rights abuses can jeopardize a new democracy's chances of survival.  This line of research marks a new direction in comparative politics that examines the relationship between transitional justice (TJ) and the quality of democratic representation. It focuses on policies aimed at vetting political candidates for acts of collaboration with the authoritarian regime, and possible human rights violations committed in the past. This process is known as lustration. In this respect, revealing evidence of past authoritarian wrongs may prevent former authoritarian elites from influencing policy in new democracies.  In preliminary work, the Principal Investigator shows that former authoritarian elites' influence tends to decrease with severity of transitional justice, but increases as voters view politicians' involvement with the former authoritarian regime as an important issue. The work also suggests that the effectiveness of TJ policies is reduced in the absence of a free press, as the media's inability to uncover empty threats which allows former autocrats to extract policy concessions. Surprisingly, the magnitude of ideological differences between current politicians and successors of authoritarian elites has no bearing on the ability of former autocrats to extract such concessions.  This research will work to develop stronger measure of TJ severity to help evaluate how transitional justice can contribute to stable democratic transitions. 

Technical Abstract
The research project will result in the creation of two novel datasets constructed to test the empirical implications of a formal theoretical model about the effects of transitional justice (TJ).  The research will analyze time series cross-sectional data to assess the role of lustration in post-authoritarian states and truth commissions in post-conflict states play in democratic consolidation. Second, the research will generate data that tracks the presence of former authoritarian elites in political parties and in the non-political sector. The overarching goal of this project is to understand how policies that increase transparency of the political process improve the quality of democratic representation in new democracies. This research will shed light on the importance of institutions accompanying transitional justice, specifically a free media, by demonstrating that lustration has the intended effect only under a precise set of conditions in the author's theoretical model. This is the first study that goes beyond studying de jure TJ institutions to study de facto TJ.  It does so by seeking to uncover the prevalence of authoritarian elites holding positions of influence following the implementation of personnel TJ. By exploring the value of revealing secret authoritarian legacies, it studies the logic of forward-looking arguments in support of TJ. In contrast to normative arguments in favor of TJ as punishing authoritarian wrong-doing, this project focuses on the truth revealing aspect of TJ and investigates whether such truth revelation enhances democratic representation.

The NSF grant has provided the PI with resources to support a research team of graduate and undergraduate students (the Transitional Justice and Democratic Stability Lab) to put together two dataset geared towards testing a theory about the effects of personnel transitional justice on the quality of democracy. I have offered these students training in dataset creation and formal and statistical methods, and I have taught them publication skills in the area of regime transitions and democratic stability. These efforts have resulted in numerous internal grants, three major publications coauthored with students, and multiple working papers. On August 29, 2020, the Lab released the Global Transitional Justice Dataset:

https://dataverse.harvard.edu/dataset.xhtml?persistentId=doi:10.7910/DVN/UK62GK

 

Additional data visualization tools and a comprehensive  Frequently Asked Question page is located on the Transitional Justice and Democratic Stability Lab’s website: https://www.tjdemstabilitylab.com/

 

Below, is the summary the theory behind the project, the activities performed, including publications followed by a paragraph describing the Broader Impacts.

 

 Theory

In an era of democratic backsliding, when fragile new democracies risk reverting back into dictatorship scholars are turning to studying transition moments for clues for why countries such  Poland, Hungary, Turkey, and Venezuela are experiencing elected incumbents gradually subverting democracy. This trend threatens the national security of the United States: the rise of authoritarian states represents a substantial threat to this country and the general global order. Can transitional justice--that is, mechanisms established by new democracies to deal with former authoritarian elites--prevent sliding back to authoritarianism? Or does such backsliding occur despite extensive transitional justice efforts? To address these issues, the Transitional Justice and Democratic Stability Lab has 1) been developing comprehensive datasets on how states deal with outgoing autocrats and their collaborators and perpetrators of human rights violations; 2) worked on formal models representing the underpinnings of transitional justice, authoritarian legacies, and democratic stability; and 3) worked on evaluating the empirical implications of the theories against novel datasets.

 

In the short term, the lab has provided undergraduate and graduate students with training in quantitative and formal methods and exposed them to cutting edge research in the field of comparative politics, which has resulted in multiple publications. In the long term, this research will help policy makers offer and evaluate improved strategies for dealing with authoritarian elites and their collaborators and help consider how new regimes may be guided toward democratic consolidation in the face of potential authoritarian backsliding.

 

Activities 
The lab’s research agenda involves 1) formalizing the mechanisms linking authoritarian legacies to prospects for successful democratization, 2) creating GIS-coded, highly disaggregated global datasets, and 3) evaluating the empirical implications of the these theories against the novel datasets. 

 

Data Collection

The second major product of the research lab accounts for the entire time series of TJ events in every country worldwide that has undergone a transition since 1946. Existing data collection efforts have coded merely the occurrence or absence of a TJ mechanism of a certain type in a given country. This project, on the other hand, has collected data on every TJ proposal and on the events that moved the proposal through the legislative process; data points include the expansion of the scope of TJ legislation and the curtailment of existing laws. This project leverages the PI’s recent work creating a time series of positive and negative TJ events for former party-based autocracies that transitioned from authoritarianism to democracy since 1946.

On September 1, 2020  PI released the Global Transitional Justice Dataset (1946-2018) to Harvard’s Dataverse, making it available to all researchers to use.

 

 Broader Implications of the Project

Since the de-Nazification policies in the U.S. zone following World War II, the U.S. has frequently dealt with former perpetrators of human rights violations and authoritarian leaders (Cohen 2006, Levy 2015). More recently, for example, the U.S. backed Iraq’s policy to purge new democratic institutions of former Ba’athists to promote societal reconciliation. De-Ba’athification prevented 185 members of Saddam Hussein’s party, mostly Sunnis, from running for the legislature in 2003 (David 2006). Many pundits and journalists have argued that such harsh policies alienating a former privileged class are exactly what prevented democratic stability from taking hold in Iraq, but they identify the alternative as “doing nothing.” However, while “doing nothing” may not produce immediate negative consequences, it may in the long-term strengthen the power of authoritarian networks. In worst-case scenarios, such reproduced networks may pave the way for an authoritarian return. My research suggests that peacemakers in Iraq should have focused on the lustration of unknown collaborators of the former authoritarian regime; these agents are in fact most threatening to new democracies. Without the disaggregation of policies into the vetting of known and unknown collaborators, such recommendations cannot be issued even as their significance for national security policy could be great.

The Lab's work has resulted in 4 published articles and a book manuscript.
